p: There are two species of HHV-6, A and B, and these are important pathogens in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients [ 76], and are common in the general population, with 90% of the population already seroconverted at the age of 1 year [ 77]. These viruses have, in addition to lymphotropic and neurotropic features, the ability to be integrated into the telomeric regions of the chromosomes of the host and subsequently to be transmitted vertically with a Mendelian pattern of inheritance, via infected organs in organ transplantations, and transplacentally [ 76]. Babies with congenitally-acquired HHV-6 may exhibit an inability to control exogenous HHV-6 and may suffer from neurological symptoms [ 76].
